Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; very worn back, though elytra line and faint division for prothorax visible; at side, legs simply detailed; underside bearing a hieroglyphic inscription arranged vertically, giving the name of Psamtek (only two hieroglyphs visible); longitudinally pierced; glaze lost; cream core of soft texture; base broken at either end of perforation.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie (probably)
Curator's comments: This scarab belongs to a type which was produced at the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming) and was distributed in the Mediterranean area, especially in Greece and Punic sites (Gorton 1996, 129-131, type XXXVI, subtype 1-7, see especially 7 for this piece). Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Petrie, W. M. F. 1889, Historical scarabs: a series of drawings from the principal collections arranged chronologically, London. Webb, V. forthcoming, 'Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site', in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 81) (more worn than on drawing)
Petrie 1889 / Historical scarabs: a series of drawings from the principal collections arranged chronologically (pl. 62, no.1973)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 129, Type XXXVI 7)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.098) (phase 3)
